We explore three ways to boost rPET availability in the US market.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fpaper%20and%20forest%20products%2Four%20insights%2Ffilling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging%2Ffilling-the-gap-boosting-supply-of-recycled-materials-for-packaging.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="filling-the-gap-boosting-supply-of-recycled-materials-for-packaging" data-layer-report-name="filling-the-gap-boosting-supply-of-recycled-materials-for-packaging>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (7 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Brand owners are continuing </strong>to introduce new packaging formats and establish innovative ways to boost product recyclability and levels of recycled content to meet their sustainable-packaging commitments, address consumer concerns, and adapt to rapidly rising regulatory pressure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="906d5fd5-08b5-4096-9a1f-ed45894f7cc0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="906d5fd5-08b5-4096-9a1f-ed45894f7cc0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/the-drive-toward-sustainability-in-packaging-beyond-the-quick-wins">The drive toward sustainability in packaging‚Äîbeyond the quick wins</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, January 30, 2020; ‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/sustainability-in-packaging-inside-the-minds-of-global-consumers">Sustainability in packaging: Inside the minds of global consumers</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, December 16, 2020; ‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/sustainability-in-packaging-global-regulatory-development-across-30-countries">Sustainability in packaging: Global regulatory development across 30 countries</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, February 7, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> However, these companies face the very real risk that they cannot achieve their goals because of an anticipated shortage of recycled materials<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ceb2cd2-08b4-4c1c-baa4-b2269c87d3bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ceb2cd2-08b4-4c1c-baa4-b2269c87d3bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/sustainability-in-packaging-five-key-levers-for-significant-impact">Sustainability in packaging: Five key levers for significant impact</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, September 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>: collection levels of high-quality recycled material look set to remain almost flat, creating supply challenges for brand owners and packaging companies. If brands with public recycled-content commitments follow through on their plans, the US demand for recycled polyethylene terephthalate (rPET) in 2030 would outpace supply by about three times. Consequently, as the supply-and-demand imbalance widens, the price premium between rPET and virgin PET has the potential to rise significantly over the next decade. The challenge for the industry moving forward will be to unlock additional rPET supply. To address this issue, we suggest three potential approaches, centered on boosting supply, ensuring access, and designing for circularity, that could also be applicable to other packaging substrates.</p>
<h2>Accelerating demand for recycled materials</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Packaging is a ubiquitous part of our daily lives. It minimizes food waste and adds convenience at low cost, but it also imposes a heavy environmental burden, given the United States‚Äô low recycling rates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="15890e45-3961-4d40-985f-0d36a3dfcbd3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="15890e45-3961-4d40-985f-0d36a3dfcbd3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/the-drive-toward-sustainability-in-packaging-beyond-the-quick-wins">The drive toward sustainability in packaging‚Äîbeyond the quick wins</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, January 30, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> This has not gone unnoticed. In recent years, consumers globally have become increasingly concerned about packaging waste and leakage into environment, and governments have begun responding to public sentiment with robust action along accelerated timelines.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="64cac5af-c471-42d8-a64e-b325f4a1172a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="64cac5af-c471-42d8-a64e-b325f4a1172a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/sustainability-in-packaging-inside-the-minds-of-global-consumers">Sustainability in packaging: Inside the minds of global consumers</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, December 16, 2020; ‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/sustainability-in-packaging-global-regulatory-development-across-30-countries">Sustainability in packaging: Global regulatory development across 30 countries</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, February 7, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In parallel, brand owners and the packaging industry have made bold commitments to improve the sustainability of their packaging portfolios through boosting recyclability and levels of recycled content.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2d6c7752-d4c5-4f26-bfec-315a277ec2b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2d6c7752-d4c5-4f26-bfec-315a277ec2b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Feber, Oskar Lingqvist, Daniel Nordig√•rden, and Matthew Seidner, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/2022-and-beyond-for-the-packaging-industrys-ceos-the-priorities-for-resilience">2022 and beyond for the packaging industry‚Äôs CEOs: The priorities for resilience</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, March 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This article is a collaborative effort by Maimouna Diakhaby, <a href="/our-people/david-feber">David Feber</a>, <a href="/our-people/yasir-mirza">Yasir Mirza</a>, <a href="/our-people/daniel-nordigarden">Daniel Nordig√•rden</a>, Brian Shields, and <a href="/our-people/jeremy-wallach">Jeremy Wallach</a>, representing views from McKinsey‚Äôs Materials Practice.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>This has increased demand for recycled materials‚Äîoften at a green price premium, given the scarcity of supply. Here, we explore the rPET value chain to understand the underlying causes of an anticipated supply-and-demand imbalance. We put forward several approaches to mitigate this issue‚Äîapproaches that we believe can also be applied to other packaging substrates (such as glass, metal, paper, and flexibles) that are facing similar market pressures.</p>
<h2>The supply-driven gap in the rPET market</h2>
<p>A diverse set of end-use applications currently relies on the PET waste stream‚Äîtextiles, plastic films, strapping, and food and beverage bottles, among others‚Äîwith PET bottles as the primary feedstock for rPET. Yet today, only about 27 percent of PET bottles and some 18 percent of all recyclable PET plastic waste are collected, with the remainder going to landfills (Exhibit 1). Over the past few years, there has been no step-change increase in PET collection or sorting. As a consequence, rPET supply has only grown at approximately 1 percent per annum over the 2012‚Äì22 period in North America.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="036accd3-9a97-491f-9741-bb00348d1813"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="036accd3-9a97-491f-9741-bb00348d1813" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis of data from Environmental Protection Agency, expert interviews, Independent Commodity Intelligence Services, and S&P Global; <em>2021 PET recycling report</em>, National Association for PET Container Resources; Sarah Edwards, <em>The 50 states of recycling: A state-by-state assessment of containers and packaging recycling rates</em>, Eunomia, March 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> While there have been some new entrants in the reclamation and reprocessing section of the value chain, there have been no significant corresponding reductions in process losses. This means that approximately 4.6 billion pounds of PET end up in landfills every year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3e825852-5379-4084-8624-113452734735"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3e825852-5379-4084-8624-113452734735" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>2021 PET recycling report</em>, National Association for PET Container Resources.</span></span></span></a></span> Collecting this unrecycled plastic represents a significant untapped opportunity to close the loop on food-grade PET.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/paper%20and%20forest%20products/our%20insights/filling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging/svgz-recycled-materials-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Only 18 percent of polyethylene terephthalate bottle waste is recycled across the US value chain." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/paper%20and%20forest%20products/our%20insights/filling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging/svgz-recycled-materials-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Importantly, rapidly growing demand, combined with stagnant supply, is expected to result in a significant future supply-and-demand imbalance for rPET (Exhibit 2):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Historically, over the 2012‚Äì22 period, we have seen rPET supply grow at only about 1 percent per annum, while consumption has increased by approximately 4 percent per annum over the same period.</li>
    <li>If brands move ahead to fully meet their stated recycled-content commitments for 2030, demand for rPET will rise by some 15 percent per annum between 2022 and 2030; over the same period, supply is expected to continue growing at only around 1 percent, resulting in demand being three times the level of available supply by 2030.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/paper%20and%20forest%20products/our%20insights/filling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging/svgz-recycled-materials-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Long-term demand for recycled polyethylene terephthalate is expected to outpace supply by 2030." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/paper%20and%20forest%20products/our%20insights/filling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging/svgz-recycled-materials-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Moving ahead, ESG-driven rPET usage will expand its share of the market, potentially leading to increasing price premiums as demand for rPET grows. Additionally, many brand owners are considering switching away from other plastic resins‚Äîsuch as high-density polyethylene (HDPE), polyvinyl chloride (PVC), and polystyrene‚Äîin favor of rPET because of its higher recyclability and its perceived accessibility compared with other resins. This could impose further supply pressures.</p>
<h2>Enablers to improve availability of recycled materials</h2>
<p>Future rPET availability will be determined by a combination of supply, demand, and regulatory factors (Exhibit 3), with plateaued supply being of greatest concern. With this in mind, packaging industry leaders can consider three meaningful ways to increase rPET availability:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong><em>Boost supply.</em></strong> With more than 80 percent of PET waste going unused, opportunities exist across the value chain to boost PET recovery, from collection through to sorting and processing. Given that recycling programs are often organized at the local level, there are opportunities to form public‚Äíprivate partnerships to increase local collection rates in areas with underfunded or nonexistent curbside recycling. The Recycling Partnership, for example, is an organization that makes private investments in public recycling programs, with the aim of increasing the supply of recycled plastics. At the same time, investments in advanced sortation equipment at material recovery facilities are an additional avenue to increasing rPET supply. We also note that in some countries (such as the Nordic countries), national and state-level policies such as extended producer responsibility or deposit-return schemes are having a measurable influence on rPET supply.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c05e4542-5424-4c7f-a8fb-f9c85825cf5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c05e4542-5424-4c7f-a8fb-f9c85825cf5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Evgenie Bogdanov et al., ‚ÄúCircular economy success: Finland‚Äôs recycling programme keeps bottles and cans off the streets,‚Äù ThisisFINLAND, updated June 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><strong><em>Ensure access.</em></strong> As rPET becomes increasingly scarce, securing access to this substrate will become critical for brands hoping to meet their recycled-content commitments. The range of strategic options for companies will vary depending on the local policy and the location of their manufacturing plants and sources of rPET supply. For example, vertical integration with a recycler and long-term strategic partnerships or contracts with suppliers or competitors are viable models that we have seen work in the plastic-packaging industry and also for other substrates: for instance, several large paper manufacturers have their own integrated recycling operations. Moreover, there have also been several small-scale efforts by brands to directly recover their own bottles from consumers. Although currently uneconomic, this approach may become viable if the value of recycled materials continues to climb and access to supply becomes more difficult.</li>
    <li><strong><em>Design for circularity.</em></strong> Brands can accelerate their path to reaching circularity commitments by assessing what ways to improve packaging design to ensure material is recovered from the waste stream. Solutions here could range from moving away from colored PET to improving labeling and product design to encourage higher rates of consumer recycling.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="950110c8-4a03-418f-a3ce-d98b1aa8c38e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="950110c8-4a03-418f-a3ce-d98b1aa8c38e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Feber, Lea Kobeli, Oskar Lingqvist, and Daniel Nordig√•rden, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/beyond-covid-19-the-next-normal-for-packaging-design">Beyond COVID-19: The next normal for packaging design</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, July 15, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> For instance, in July 2022, Coca-Cola announced that its Sprite brand would no longer use green-colored PET plastic, which has historically been harder to recycle into future food-grade bottle uses. This change improves the circularity of the bottles by avoiding them being converted into products such as carpeting or clothing, which generally cannot be recycled today.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/paper%20and%20forest%20products/our%20insights/filling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging/svgz-recycled-materials-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Several key themes will affect the stability of the recycled polyethylene terephthalate market in the United States." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/paper%20and%20forest%20products/our%20insights/filling%20the%20gap%20boosting%20supply%20of%20recycled%20materials%20for%20packaging/svgz-recycled-materials-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Importantly, we anticipate that these three enablers will also be applicable to other substrates across the broader packaging market, such as the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong><em>Paper packaging.</em></strong> Currently, there is a well-developed recycling regimen for old corrugated containers used in paperboard packaging. However, a large volume of mixed papers still goes to landfills. As such, this represents a major unused resource for packaging companies to tap into to raise the recycled content in various categories of paper packaging.</li>
    <li><strong><em>Metal packaging.</em></strong> Securing access to used beverage cans and scrap metal has become a strategic issue for beverage packaging companies, with only about 45 percent of aluminum currently recycled by consumers in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4dca1cc-f2f2-41fe-8dc8-79060f266ece"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4dca1cc-f2f2-41fe-8dc8-79060f266ece" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The aluminum can advantage: Sustainability key performance indicators,</em> The Aluminum Association and Can Manufacturers Institute, November 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Metal producers have been investing in recycling infrastructure and sortation technology to access and consume more recycled materials.</li>
    <li><strong><em>Glass packaging.</em></strong> Only 25 percent of glass is currently collected in the US due to high labor and sorting costs, along with the significant cost of transportation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="72dd3f67-430b-4699-b3ab-46a6db0f9991"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="72dd3f67-430b-4699-b3ab-46a6db0f9991" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúNational overview: Facts and figures on materials, wasters and recycling,‚Äù US Environmental Protection Agency, accessed July 28, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> While regulation in this area has been limited, most cullet<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e00bd0d2-1fb7-4095-b96e-5f908d1f849e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e00bd0d2-1fb7-4095-b96e-5f908d1f849e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cullet refers to glass that has been crushed and is ready to be remelted.</span></span></span></a></span> supply comes from bottle-bill states.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3290202d-8409-4717-8818-2920affb1698"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3290202d-8409-4717-8818-2920affb1698" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bottle-bill states in the United States are those states that have beverage container deposit laws in place.</span></span></span></a></span> Finding ways to reduce recycling costs alongside light-weighting initiatives could improve cullet use in new glass production.</li>
    <li><strong><em>Flexible packaging.</em></strong> The most significant challenge today is that not all recycling systems are equipped to collect and recycle this type of packaging, resulting in low recycling rates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d9551bb7-8775-4a2f-88dd-2f91072ae3a8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d9551bb7-8775-4a2f-88dd-2f91072ae3a8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúFlexible packaging: The urgent actions needed to deliver circular economy solutions,‚Äù Ellen MacArthur Foundation, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Designing for higher recyclability via new materials (for example, fully recyclable films) and structural redesigns (which make components easy to separate for consumers) could be two routes to improving circularity.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>Sustainability in packaging is a time-sensitive priority for leaders in the packaging industry. Achieving true circularity through higher concentrations of recycled materials is a critical enabler. However, the significant challenge will be for the supply side to keep pace with demand during the remaining years of this decade. There is no time to waste, with multiple ambitious sustainability commitments scheduled for 2025 fast approaching.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Maimouna Diakhaby</strong> is an associate partner in McKinsey‚Äôs Washington office, <strong><a href="/our-people/david-feber">David Feber</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Detroit office, <strong><a href="/our-people/yasir-mirza">Yasir Mirza</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Atlanta office, <strong><a href="/our-people/daniel-nordigarden">Daniel Nordig√•rden</a></strong> is a partner in the Toronto office, <strong>Brian Shields</strong> is a consultant in the Pittsburgh office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/jeremy-wallach">Jeremy Wallach</a></strong> is a partner in the Boston office.</p>

demand for recycled content in packaging could lead to shortages of recycled packaging materials. We explore three ways to boost rPET availability in the US market."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"High long-term demand for recycled content in packaging could lead to shortages of recycled packaging materials. How can the US boost rPET availability?"},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-09-05T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBrand owners are continuing \u003c/strong\u003eto introduce new packaging formats and establish innovative ways to boost product recyclability and levels of recycled content to meet their sustainable-packaging commitments, address consumer concerns, and adapt to rapidly rising regulatory pressure.[[footnote 1]] However, these companies face the very real risk that they cannot achieve their goals because of an anticipated shortage of recycled materials[[footnote 2]]: collection levels of high-quality recycled material look set to remain almost flat, creating supply challenges for brand owners and packaging companies. If brands with public recycled-content commitments follow through on their plans, the US demand for recycled polyethylene terephthalate (rPET) in 2030 would outpace supply by about three times. Consequently, as the supply-and-demand imbalance widens, the price premium between rPET and virgin PET has the potential to rise significantly over the next decade. The challenge for the industry moving forward will be to unlock additional rPET supply. To address this issue, we suggest three potential approaches, centered on boosting supply, ensuring access, and designing for circularity, that could also be applicable to other packaging substrates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAccelerating demand for recycled materials\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003ePackaging is a ubiquitous part of our daily lives. It minimizes food waste and adds convenience at low cost, but it also imposes a heavy environmental burden, given the United States\u0026rsquo; low recycling rates.[[footnote 3]] This has not gone unnoticed. In recent years, consumers globally have become increasingly concerned about packaging waste and leakage into environment, and governments have begun responding to public sentiment with robust action along accelerated timelines.[[footnote 4]] In parallel, brand owners and the packaging industry have made bold commitments to improve the sustainability of their packaging portfolios through boosting recyclability and levels of recycled content.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis has increased demand for recycled materials\u0026mdash;often at a green price premium, given the scarcity of supply. Here, we explore the rPET value chain to understand the underlying causes of an anticipated supply-and-demand imbalance. We put forward several approaches to mitigate this issue\u0026mdash;approaches that we believe can also be applied to other packaging substrates (such as glass, metal, paper, and flexibles) that are facing similar market pressures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe supply-driven gap in the rPET market\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA diverse set of end-use applications currently relies on the PET waste stream\u0026mdash;textiles, plastic films, strapping, and food and beverage bottles, among others\u0026mdash;with PET bottles as the primary feedstock for rPET. Yet today, only about 27 percent of PET bottles and some 18 percent of all recyclable PET plastic waste are collected, with the remainder going to landfills (Exhibit 1). Over the past few years, there has been no step-change increase in PET collection or sorting. As a consequence, rPET supply has only grown at approximately 1 percent per annum over the 2012\u0026ndash;22 period in North America.[[footnote 6]] While there have been some new entrants in the reclamation and reprocessing section of the value chain, there have been no significant corresponding reductions in process losses. This means that approximately 4.6 billion pounds of PET end up in landfills every year.[[footnote 7]] Collecting this unrecycled plastic represents a significant untapped opportunity to close the loop on food-grade PET.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eImportantly, rapidly growing demand, combined with stagnant supply, is expected to result in a significant future supply-and-demand imbalance for rPET (Exhibit 2):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHistorically, over the 2012\u0026ndash;22 period, we have seen rPET supply grow at only about 1 percent per annum, while consumption has increased by approximately 4 percent per annum over the same period.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIf brands move ahead to fully meet their stated recycled-content commitments for 2030, demand for rPET will rise by some 15 percent per annum between 2022 and 2030; over the same period, supply is expected to continue growing at only around 1 percent, resulting in demand being three times the level of available supply by 2030.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eMoving ahead, ESG-driven rPET usage will expand its share of the market, potentially leading to increasing price premiums as demand for rPET grows. Additionally, many brand owners are considering switching away from other plastic resins\u0026mdash;such as high-density polyethylene (HDPE), polyvinyl chloride (PVC), and polystyrene\u0026mdash;in favor of rPET because of its higher recyclability and its perceived accessibility compared with other resins. This could impose further supply pressures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEnablers to improve availability of recycled materials\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFuture rPET availability will be determined by a combination of supply, demand, and regulatory factors (Exhibit 3), with plateaued supply being of greatest concern. With this in mind, packaging industry leaders can consider three meaningful ways to increase rPET availability:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBoost supply.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e With more than 80 percent of PET waste going unused, opportunities exist across the value chain to boost PET recovery, from collection through to sorting and processing. Given that recycling programs are often organized at the local level, there are opportunities to form public‚Äíprivate partnerships to increase local collection rates in areas with underfunded or nonexistent curbside recycling. The Recycling Partnership, for example, is an organization that makes private investments in public recycling programs, with the aim of increasing the supply of recycled plastics. At the same time, investments in advanced sortation equipment at material recovery facilities are an additional avenue to increasing rPET supply. We also note that in some countries (such as the Nordic countries), national and state-level policies such as extended producer responsibility or deposit-return schemes are having a measurable influence on rPET supply.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnsure access.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e As rPET becomes increasingly scarce, securing access to this substrate will become critical for brands hoping to meet their recycled-content commitments. The range of strategic options for companies will vary depending on the local policy and the location of their manufacturing plants and sources of rPET supply. For example, vertical integration with a recycler and long-term strategic partnerships or contracts with suppliers or competitors are viable models that we have seen work in the plastic-packaging industry and also for other substrates: for instance, several large paper manufacturers have their own integrated recycling operations. Moreover, there have also been several small-scale efforts by brands to directly recover their own bottles from consumers. Although currently uneconomic, this approach may become viable if the value of recycled materials continues to climb and access to supply becomes more difficult.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eDesign for circularity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Brands can accelerate their path to reaching circularity commitments by assessing what ways to improve packaging design to ensure material is recovered from the waste stream. Solutions here could range from moving away from colored PET to improving labeling and product design to encourage higher rates of consumer recycling.[[footnote 9]] For instance, in July 2022, Coca-Cola announced that its Sprite brand would no longer use green-colored PET plastic, which has historically been harder to recycle into future food-grade bottle uses. This change improves the circularity of the bottles by avoiding them being converted into products such as carpeting or clothing, which generally cannot be recycled today.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eImportantly, we anticipate that these three enablers will also be applicable to other substrates across the broader packaging market, such as the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ePaper packaging.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Currently, there is a well-developed recycling regimen for old corrugated containers used in paperboard packaging. However, a large volume of mixed papers still goes to landfills. As such, this represents a major unused resource for packaging companies to tap into to raise the recycled content in various categories of paper packaging.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eMetal packaging.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Securing access to used beverage cans and scrap metal has become a strategic issue for beverage packaging companies, with only about 45 percent of aluminum currently recycled by consumers in the United States.[[footnote 10]] Metal producers have been investing in recycling infrastructure and sortation technology to access and consume more recycled materials.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eGlass packaging.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Only 25 percent of glass is currently collected in the US due to high labor and sorting costs, along with the significant cost of transportation.[[footnote 11]] While regulation in this area has been limited, most cullet[[footnote 12]] supply comes from bottle-bill states.[[footnote 13]] Finding ways to reduce recycling costs alongside light-weighting initiatives could improve cullet use in new glass production.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFlexible packaging.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e The most significant challenge today is that not all recycling systems are equipped to collect and recycle this type of packaging, resulting in low recycling rates.[[footnote 14]] Designing for higher recyclability via new materials (for example, fully recyclable films) and structural redesigns (which make components easy to separate for consumers) could be two routes to improving circularity.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSustainability in packaging is a time-sensitive priority for leaders in the packaging industry. Achieving true circularity through higher concentrations of recycled materials is a critical enabler. However, the significant challenge will be for the supply side to keep pace with demand during the remaining years of this decade. There is no time to waste, with multiple ambitious sustainability commitments scheduled for 2025 fast approaching.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
